title: Case Study 8: Traumatic Tympanic Membrane Perforation
chief_complaint: My hearing has been 'a bit off' in my right ear since an accident with a cotton swab four days ago.

problem_summary.course: Incident caused immediate severe pain which has since subsided. Hearing difficulty persists.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of ear status following trauma.

history.present_illness: Patient was cleaning ears with a cotton swab 4 days ago when her boyfriend bumped into her. This caused the swab to injure the right ear, resulting in great pain. The pain has subsided, but she notices a change in hearing.
history.patient_goals: Determine cause of hearing change and status of the ear.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear tympanogram is flat (Type B) with an abnormally large ear canal volume (Vea), consistent with a tympanic membrane perforation. Left ear tympanogram is normal (Type A).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear thresholds are within normal limits (0-5 dB HL). Right ear shows a mild low-frequency conductive hearing loss with an air-bone gap. Bone conduction thresholds are normal bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition scores in both ears.

tests.name: Wideband Acoustic Immittance
tests.key_findings: Reflectance graph provided showing differences between Right (solid) and Left (dashed) ears, consistent with middle ear pathology in the Right ear.

overall_audiologic_summary: The evaluation reveals a mild conductive hearing loss in the right ear. Tympanometry findings (Type B with large ear canal volume) strongly indicate a tympanic membrane perforation in the right ear, consistent with the reported trauma. The left ear presents with normal hearing sensitivity and normal middle ear function.
counseling_points: The tests confirm you have a perforation (hole) in your right eardrum caused by the cotton swab.
The 'flat' pressure test with the high volume reading is the key sign of this perforation.
This hole is the cause of the slight hearing loss you are noticing.
It is very important to keep the ear dry. Use a cotton ball with Vaseline or an earplug when showering to prevent water from entering the middle ear.
We will monitor the ear, as many traumatic perforations heal spontaneously over time.
notes_for_actor: You are a young adult (21 years old).
You feel a bit embarrassed that this happened while cleaning your ears.
You are relieved the pain is gone but anxious about whether the 'hole' will close up on its own.
Ask if you need surgery or if it will heal by itself.
